title: How to Cover a Corset

steps.headline: Pin your corset down flat on a stretch of paper.
steps.description: Unbutton your corset and lay it flat on a stretch of white paper. Use sewing pins to hold down the ends of your corset so that it doesn’t move around.Try using a long stretch of parchment paper if you can’t find any sheets that are big enough to fit your corset.

steps.headline: Poke pins around the outline of each section to mark out a pattern.
steps.description: Find the sections of your corset that have been sewn together by looking for the seams in your garment. Hold a sharp sewing pin and poke holes straight down into the seams of your corset every 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) or so to create a pattern on your paper.Tip: If you have a corset pattern already, you don’t need to make one out of your existing corset. Most corsets have about 6 sections on the front and back, but it can vary.

steps.headline: Remove the corset from the paper.
steps.description: Take out the sewing pins from your corset and gently pick it up off of the paper. Make sure you don’t crease or wrinkle your piece of paper as you move your corset around.

steps.headline: Cut out each section from the paper.
steps.description: Use sharp scissors to cut out each section of your pattern to separate the pieces. Make sure each section lines up with the fabric sections on your corset by double checking them against your garment after you’ve cut them out.You don’t need to add a seam allowance to the pieces of paper, since you can do that later on when cutting out your fabric.

steps.headline: Pin the pattern pieces onto your new fabric.
steps.description: Lay out your new fabric on a flat surface. Set each piece of pattern paper onto the fabric with a 1 in (2.5 cm) margin on each side. Use 2 to 3 sewing pins on each edge of the pattern paper to pin them down onto the fabric.Look for a non-stretchy fabric that will be easier to sew, like cotton or a linen blend. Leaving a margin is important so you have room to sew your pieces onto your corset.

steps.headline: Cut pattern pieces out of your new fabric.
steps.description: Use sharp scissors to cut around each piece of paper, leaving the 1 in (2.5 cm) margin around each edge. Make sure each piece is cut straight and without many jagged edges.

steps.headline: Line up each new fabric piece with your corset.
steps.description: Remove the paper from the new fabric pieces and align each one with their corresponding spaces on your corset. Fold over the edges of each fabric piece about 1 in (2.5 cm) so that they match the size of each section. Use sewing pins around the edges to pin them into place by inserting them perpendicular to the seams of each fabric piece.Folding over the edges makes a nice hem line so you can’t see the raw edges of the fabric.

steps.headline: Sew the new fabric onto your corset with a running stitch.
steps.description: Pick your needle up through the corset and the fabric and then bring it back down again. Then, bring your needle back up through both layers. Attach all of your pieces of fabric in the same way.A running stitch is easy to remove if you decide to uncover your corset later.

methods.name: Wearing Undergarments to Hide Your Corset

steps.headline: Choose a corset cover for the simplest option.
steps.description: Corset covers are designed to be worn over corsets underneath your clothes. They are usually made of thin, cream-colored fabric with buttons or snaps on the front and hit around your natural waistline. They may have small cap sleeves or they could be strapless. Put one of these on to hide the color or appearance of your corset.You can find corset covers and other undergarments at most costume stores, or you can make one yourself by finding a pattern online.

steps.headline: Wear an underbodice for more coverage.
steps.description: Underbodices are similar to corset covers, but they are usually thicker and may have longer sleeves. Put an underbodice on for extra silhouette support or another layer of warmth on a chilly day.Some underbodices have boning in them to help support your silhouette.

steps.headline: Add a chemisette to your outfit for an extra collar.
steps.description: Chemisettes, which can be sleeveless or have small cap sleeves, are made to fit loosely around a corset and hide the harsh outlines, but they also have large, fantastic collars that stick out of your shirt. Put one of these on for a fancy occasion or to add some flair to your look.Chemisettes look great under simple dresses to add a touch of flair.

steps.headline: Put on a loose camisole for an easy solution.
steps.description: Tight tank tops or camisoles can adhere to your corset and make the harsh boning lines stand out more. Try putting on a camisole that is 2 sizes larger than you would normally wear to hide the curves of your corset and make your silhouette look smoother.Tip: Camisoles usually have spaghetti straps so they are easier to hide under T-shirts.

Corset covers are designed to be worn over corsets underneath your clothes.
They are usually made of thin, cream-colored fabric with buttons or snaps on the front and hit around your natural waistline.
They may have small cap sleeves or they could be strapless.
Put one of these on to hide the color or appearance of your corset.You can find corset covers and other undergarments at most costume stores, or you can make one yourself by finding a pattern online.
Wear an underbodice for more coverage.
Underbodices are similar to corset covers, but they are usually thicker and may have longer sleeves.

Add a chemisette to your outfit for an extra collar.

Chemisettes, which can be sleeveless or have small cap sleeves, are made to fit loosely around a corset and hide the harsh outlines, but they also have large, fantastic collars that stick out of your shirt.
Put one of these on for a fancy occasion or to add some flair to your look.Chemisettes look great under simple dresses to add a touch of flair.
